div.p: David Lindsay to Alexander Magarey and James Jones
Collection of the Royal Geographical Society of Australasia (South Australia Branch) Inc., State Library of South Australia, Adelaide.
Adelaide
12th Feby 1887
The Hon Secretaries
S.A Branch R.G.S.A.
Adelaide
Gentlemen,

herewith I have the honor to forward a detailed statement of expenses incurred through taking Lieutenant Dittrich as Botanical collector &c on my recent journey across Australia, also a copy of an account against me which was sent by Lieut Dittrich, enclosed in a most insulting letter, two hours after he sailed for Melbourne and fourteen (14) days after I had furnished him, with a statement; the whole of this time he was in Adelaide and made no claim. I merely acknowledged receipt of this letter. A few days ago I received another insulting letter from him threatening legal proceedings unless his claim for £18.0.1 be settled by a certain date (3rd Febr.) of this letter I have taken no notice whatever, being quite satisfied that he has no just claim on me.
I also enclose a statement of account between him and me.
I am troubling you with these matters so that if at any future time this affair should crop up you will be in possession of the facts.

Mr Dittrich's offer was to accompany me for his expenses and outfit. My statements as to the journey I proposed to undertake concluded by saying that after reaching the McArthur River my movements were doubtful Nothing was ever said or written between him & myself about the return journey.
You will remember that I stated, when asking the Government or the Geographical Society for assistance to enable me to take a botanical collector, that Baron Von Mueller had promised me £20.

After numerous letters passing between the Baron and myself re payment of that sum, he wrote me last week that he had been induced to pay the balance of the £20 (he having some time previously paid £10 to Mr D.) to Mr Dittrich because, to use his own words "Lieutenant Dittrich was here in so great a difficulty after his return as to induce me to pay him also the second instalment of the £20 which I originally promised for the botanic collector as a contribution of mine. He having had no salary could not be left quite helpless here and I feel sure no one will grudge him this small sum after so long a journey. One of the reasons also why I paid the full sum to him was this that for several months he enjoyed the hospitality of the squatters away from the party so that he had then no need to draw on the Expedition stores." To this letter from Baron Von Mueller I replied pointing out — that I thought, the proper way of looking at this question was - Did he - the Baron — promise to pay me £20 as an inducement for me to make a collection of botanical specimens? If so — he should have paid it — If he did not promise it to me - then whether he paid Lieut Dittrich any sum, large or small, had nothing whatever to do with me, and intimating surprise that he could have hesitated what to do in this matter.

I also enclosed a pressed copy of the statement, now forwarded to you, showing the expenses I was put to on which he will see I have only considered the rations as for 9 months whereas the expedition lasted 12 months from Hergott
Hergott's Springs, now Maree, SA.
to McArthur River. Farther drawing his attention to the expenses for a Camera and informing him that all the photographs taken - save two were worthless.

In regard to the items in Mr Dittrich's account against me — Fare by steamer has been allowed — His claim for £1 for cab to go to Williamstown could not be entertained as he should have gone by train at a cost of 1/- "Telegrams & Cab hire 8/- - " Cabhire 10/- was allowed. As regards clothing. When he arrived I showed him the list of clothing I had purchased for myself, and said I would get the same for him. He replied "I do not want singlets sox or handkerchiefs and I have one towel and would rather take this Helmet — I have had it in different countries for the past 3 or 4 years-" I therefore did not purchase those things although I offered to do so if he chose to leave those he had brought with him. The price I paid for my singlets was 12/9. Helmet hat 7/9 sox 8/6 - I supplied him with two towels — I only took 3 myself. The boots he must have carried in his swag because those I supplied him he wore from Hergott to Port Darwin. Bush knife he brought with him — Under any circumstances fancy knives are not supplied - Boatman 1/- I allowed for - Difference steerage & saloon passage Port Darwin to Sydney £8. He did not pay that amount so therefore has no claim.

As in a previous letter I informed you that I took steerage or second class tickets for the four of us who were returning - I did this because of his insulting and generally disagreeable behaviour throughout the trip and while in P. Darwin.

In my account I have charged him with the money he received for the Rifle viz £5-0-0 and have given a credit on my account of expenses for the amount of £2-6-0 which I would otherwise have had to pay Mr Dittrich.

I regret very much that the photographs were all failures. I cannot account for it as Mr Dittrich had all material and assistance he required. This much I may say that he obstinately refused to accept any suggestions I might make about photographing. For instance, at Dalhousie, where we were most kindly treated, I asked him to photograph the station with the Messrs Smith & Bagot on the verhandah, as they had expressed a desire to have one. At first he said he would not - but afterwards did, without advising any one of his intention consequently the place was shut up and two members of my party were on the verandah attending to some of the camp equipment. At Powell's Creek telegraph station I also asked him to take a photograph of the Station — He did so when the house was closed and the station master away. From such a distance was the photograph taken that had the picture been a clear one, the houses would have shown but as mere white specks

I have handed over the photo camera & the unused plates. The tripod Lieutenant Dittrich had in his swag and kept it. In fact he kept every thing he could lay his hands on. — The compass was lost and the revolver Mr D refused to return to me. The collection of botanical specimens have I believe been sent by the Hon the Minister of Education to Dr Schomburg

On the arrival of my Camels at Hergott I proceeded to that place and arranged for the return to Mr Lyndhurst of Sir Thos Elder's Camel at a cost of £2+10+0. This was the lowest sum I could induce Tayhe Mahomet to send her across for. This expense should I think not be borne by me. If you agree to pay it please forward it up Davey & Pilkington as agents for Taighe Mahomet.
I have forwarded a collection of native weapons and implements to the Society's rooms.
Did Lieutenant Dittrich have your permission to forward to Mr Curr of Melbourne a copy of all information gained by him concerning the natives?
